Question
========

In the following paper, the authors [published a data set of online profiles of nearly 70,000 OkCupid users](https://fortune.com/2016/05/18/okcupid-data-research/):

- Kirkegaard, Emil OW, and Julius D Bjerrekær. 2016. “The OKCupid Dataset: A Very Large Public Dataset of Dating Site Users.” Open Differential Psychology 46.

One purported purpose of the paper was to investigate the relationship between each person's [astrological sign](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astrological_sign) (see link for explanation) and their personality. The study was later retracted. 

Which of the following statements are true?

Answerlist
----------
* The authors did not obtain [informed consent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Informed_consent) from the OkCupid users before publishing their data online.
* There is no potential harm in published dating profiles that people have already willingly put online.
* This study was justified because most scientists would agree that the research question has significant scientific merit. 
* Because the study was later retracted, it's not possible that any harm was done. 

Solution
========

Answerlist
----------
* True.
* False. There is significant potential harm. Some users may express preferences for same-sex relationships but live in countries where that behavior is illegal.
* False. Astrology is generally considered a pseudoscience. 
* False. It's possible that others could have copied the data before it was taken down.
